On 10/12/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>
> Is this th=
ing on?
>
> NOT ALL ASSERTIONS ARE assertEquals()!
>
> If I just get Assert=
ionFailedError at line 23 because assertNotNull()
> failed, I have /no idea=
/ which row of test data caused that failure.
>
> That said, test names is =
the way I usually solve this problem. I admit
> there are other solutions, =
but if you don't let me give you a test name,
> then you /force/ me to use =
a failure message (to display, for example,
> enough input data to distingu=
ish one test from another) when I otherwise
> wouldn't have needed one. Mor=
e work than necessary.


Point taken :-)

Still, I think this is a differen=
t topic. Having a meaningful failure
message is orthogonal to whether this =
test method received parameters or
not.

Once in a while, I will bother add=
ing a failure message in the assert, but
most of the time, I don't and if t=
here's a failure, I need to dig in anyway
so the stack trace is usually goo=
d enough to get me started.

Again, I'm not ruling out adding test names to=
 Data Providers, just taking
things one step at a time in order to see how =
users will use this feature.

--
C=E9dric
